name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

key_work.title: Long Way to the Top – AC/DC
key_work.credit_line: ℗ 1976 J. Albert & Sons Pty Ltd. (Young / Scott / Young)
key_work.brief_description: The music video for AC/DC’s hit that featured the ban travelling down Melbourne’s Swanston street on the back of a truck, which helped lead to the band having a laneway named after them.

constellations_primary.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_primary.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

start.title: Horror Movie – Skyhooks
start.brief_description: The colourful and quirky music video for Skyhooks’ song ‘Horror Movie’ (1974) helped mark Australian television’s transition from black and white to colour as it was first played on a special, midnight episode of Countdown (1974–87).

constellations_primary.name: Horror movie right there on my TV
constellations_primary.description: The colourful and quirky music video for Skyhooks’ song 'Horror Movie' helped propel them to number one, making it their biggest hit.

constellations_other.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_other.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

end.title: The Secret Life of Us
end.brief_description: The Secret Life of Us is an Australian television drama series about the lives of 20-30 somethings living in the early 2000s.

constellations_other.name: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
constellations_other.description: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls explores the reality of living in Mparntwe (Alice Springs) through the eyes of the artists, who grew up there. Place and Indigenous representation are also vital to the other works in this Constellation.

constellations_other.name: 2000s TV
constellations_other.description: The dawn of the new millennium brought a wave of Australian programming that was more ambitious and bolder than previous decades.

constellations_other.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_other.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

constellations_other.name: Raising the Roof: on-screen levity on rooftop
constellations_other.description: Performances soar to new heights on the rooftop, not only showcasing skylines but also creating electrifying drama, comedy and spectacle.

links.description: ‘Horror Movie’ reflected the pessimism of the 1970s with the nightly news likened to a horror movie. No wonder the band filmed part of the video in a happier place – Melbourne’s Lunar Park, which also appeared prominently in The Secret Life of Us.

start.title: Long Way to the Top – AC/DC
start.credit_line: ℗ 1976 J. Albert & Sons Pty Ltd. (Young / Scott / Young)
start.brief_description: The music video for AC/DC’s hit that featured the ban travelling down Melbourne’s Swanston street on the back of a truck, which helped lead to the band having a laneway named after them.

constellations_primary.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_primary.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

end.title: RocKwiz
end.brief_description: RocKwiz is an Australian television quiz show series, focused on rock music and featuring different guest artist musicians who perform live in each episode. It is broadcast on SBS One and premiered in 2005. As of August 2013 it is in its 11th season.

constellations_other.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_other.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

links.description: Director Paul Drane not only made ‘It’s A Long Way to the Top’ for Countdown, he’s also directed countless other film clips and concerts. And he’s still going strong in the music biz, since 2005, he’s directed episodes of music trivia show RockWiz.

start.title: Countdown
start.brief_description: Countdown was a long-running popular weekly Australian music television show broadcast by the ABC from 8 November 1974 until 19 July 1987.

constellations_other.name: 1970s TV
constellations_other.description: The 1970s was a thrilling time in Australian television as productions expanded in scale, scope, and ambition.

constellations_other.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_other.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

end.title: Molly
end.creator_credit: John Molloy, Mushroom Pictures, M4 Entertainment Production and Liz Doran
end.brief_description: From humble beginnings in Quambatook, Ian Meldrum rose to become the most influential and well known name in Australian music.

constellations_other.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_other.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

links.description: The story of Countdown‘s iconic, Stetson-wearing host, Ian ‘Molly’ Meldrum was dramatised in the miniseries Molly (2016), which charts the groundbreaking show’s rise and decline, along with Molly’s personal life.

start.title: Molly
start.creator_credit: John Molloy, Mushroom Pictures, M4 Entertainment Production and Liz Doran
start.brief_description: From humble beginnings in Quambatook, Ian Meldrum rose to become the most influential and well known name in Australian music.

links.description: Molly was played in the miniseries by Samuel Johnson, who also starred in The Secret Life of Us, providing voice-over for most of the episodes, except sections performed by Deborah Mailman as the character Kelly Lewis.

constellations_other.name: Raising the Roof: on-screen levity on rooftop
constellations_other.description: Performances soar to new heights on the rooftop, not only showcasing skylines but also creating electrifying drama, comedy and spectacle.

links.description: While The Secret Life of Us put the suburb of St. Kilda on the TV map, it’s also the home of The Esplanade Hotel, known commonly as The Espy, where episodes of Rockwiz were filmed in The Gershwin Room.

start.title: The Secret Life of Us
start.brief_description: The Secret Life of Us is an Australian television drama series about the lives of 20-30 somethings living in the early 2000s.

end.title: Redfern Now

video_links.name: Redfern Now | Starts 8.30pm on Thursday, 1 Nov 2012, ABC1

end.brief_description: Redfern Now is a kaleidoscopic drama that explores this inner-city suburb and the people who inhabit it. The highly celebrated and multi award-winning drama series written, directed and produced by Indigenous creatives.

constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

constellations_other.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_other.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

constellations_other.name: Landscape as Character
constellations_other.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

constellations_other.name: Canopy
constellations_other.description: John Harvey is a Torres Strait Islander producer, director and writer in screen and stage whose work Canopy celebrates Indigenous self-representation.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

links.description: The real suburb of St. Kilda was intrinsic to the success of The Secret Life of Us, with the show’s stories given a unique sensibility based on the location. Similarly, Redfern Now follows the lives of people living in the real Sydney suburb of Redfern. Both series also star Deborah Mailman.

start.title: Long Way to the Top – AC/DC
start.credit_line: ℗ 1976 J. Albert & Sons Pty Ltd. (Young / Scott / Young)
start.brief_description: The music video for AC/DC’s hit that featured the ban travelling down Melbourne’s Swanston street on the back of a truck, which helped lead to the band having a laneway named after them.

end.title: Countdown

constellations_other.name: 1970s TV
constellations_other.description: The 1970s was a thrilling time in Australian television as productions expanded in scale, scope, and ambition.

constellations_other.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_other.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

links.description: One of the most iconic Australian rock anthems of all-time, the music video followed the band playing down Melbourne’s Swanston St on the back of a truck. Permission was revoked but the rockers did it anyway. Director Paul Drane shot the video to appear on Countdown.

start.title: Countdown
start.brief_description: Countdown was a long-running popular weekly Australian music television show broadcast by the ABC from 8 November 1974 until 19 July 1987.

end.title: Horror Movie – Skyhooks
end.brief_description: The colourful and quirky music video for Skyhooks’ song ‘Horror Movie’ (1974) helped mark Australian television’s transition from black and white to colour as it was first played on a special, midnight episode of Countdown (1974–87).

constellations_primary.name: Horror movie right there on my TV
constellations_primary.description: The colourful and quirky music video for Skyhooks’ song 'Horror Movie' helped propel them to number one, making it their biggest hit.

constellations_other.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_other.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

links.description: Hosted by Ian ‘Molly’ Meldrum, this weekly music show launched the careers of countless Australian musicians and hosted international guests. One of those bands was glam-rockers Skyhooks, whose ‘Horror Movie’ went to number 1 after being performed on the show.
